column4: If i want to set up network authentication at home is ldap the best way to go ? I have Mac and Ubuntu desktops/notebooks
LDAP is very nice, especially on a large (wireless) network (RADIUS!) . It takes some configuration though.
I have a mix of wireless (g&&n) and wired (gigabit)
nice!, how many stations are attached to your LAN?
right now i've got 6 running osx and 2 boxes running ubuntu
sounds like a nice network indeed. If you go into the trouble of setting up LDAP combined with a radius server, that's about the safest option you can choose (provided you use WPA2 of course).
how would the wired machines log on to the network? I want to be able to have a central home directory for everyone so I'd either export nfs or netatalk (or a combination of the two)
the nice thing about LDAP is that you can roam freely on the network when logging in. The disadvantage is that you need to have your LDAP/ radius server running at all times.
the wired computers should use pam_LDAP to authenticate to your central LDAP-server.

ah okay great. I have been having trouble getting everything to work properly. i can query the ldap server with slapcat and ldapsearch but am still unable to authenticate to it. i've installed ldapscripts and can use ldapadduesr ldapmodifyuser etc without problem but when i try to login using one of those created accounts -- no dice
it takes a while to setup, but it's great, especially when coupled with radius, nfs and local DNS

I need to spend a bit more time getting dns set up properly. I have been using /etc/hosts and it's really doing my head in. I am trying to build things one step at a time so not to over complicate things
there are a few things on the ubuntu guide that have me a bit confused
true, for a small static network a hosts file is a simple alternative indeed.

maybe I can help you with that, but I doubt it. I am enthousiastic about this combination because it has been implemented where I work and I know it to work comfortably. I have never set it up myself :-/

as of now i am working at a company that has sort of outgrown its authentication mechanism (standard growing pains) and i am hoping to learn a bit about openldap so to get away from passwd/shadow editing using puppet on hundreds of hosts... i sort of joined the company and realized what they were doing and was frightened lol

Good show! This will definitely impress your staff once you get it up and running. One disadvantage is that the machines will become totally dependent on that LDAP server, if it goes down, no one can login anymore. That is, if you use LDAP login exclusively.
